entry.title: By: Eli Weinstock-Herman (tarwn)
entry.content:
I’ve looked at it in the past. It’s definitely a handy way to hook JavaScript tests into the VisualStudio environment. I believe I tried it out on my sqlishard.com project and wired into it the TeamCity build too. When I was using it this way, I still had to kick off all my tests manually when I made changes, so it didn’t buy me much over using a SpecRunner.html file in a browser.

I’m not sure I would consider this to be closer to NCrunch. NCrunch runs my .Net build and tests continuously as it detects me making changes in the workspace, showing a visual indicator in the bottom right of build failures, test failures or every ok. The test runner that shows details has a better display than the Visual Studio one, showing the full hierarchy and making it easy to re-run, debug, ignore or add in tests, etc. But that’s just the beginning, on top of all of that it shows coverage indicators in the Visual Studio window for the tests it has run, highlights longer-running lines by altering the color of the coverage dot, and allows me to right-click any dot and immediately run a test in debug mode to break at that line. Exceptions are displayed as X’s and show their detail in a mouseover, so I can explore the exact stack of calls the exception traversed without re-running the test even once.

Don’t get me wrong, I like Chutzpah, the differences are really down to what the Visual Studio test runner provides vs NCrunch’s more extensive capabilities. It also hasn’t annoyed me to the same level keeping karma’s dependencies stable has.
